awd_titl_txt: FmitF: Track II: KeenEye: Enhancing Scenario Exploration
awd_abstract_narration:
Scenario-finding toolsets are used to help computer scientists explore the correctness of their software by generating different examples of behavior allowed by the software system. Then, a user inspects these scenarios and makes sure the behavior matches their expectation. Since this inspection process is often done manually, scenario-finding tool sets should produce the fewest unique scenarios without missing important behavior. This project focuses on improvements to the scenario-finding toolset of the Alloy Analyzer. The project’s novelties are two-fold. First, this project integrates different enumeration strategies in the Alloy Analyzer to generate a more succinct collection of valuable scenarios. Second, this project improves the visual display of these scenarios so that computer scientists can more easily assess them for correct behavior. The project’s impacts are seen in the improved productivity of Alloy users who will no longer need to invest an intensive amount of time to build confidence in the correctness of their system.

This project enhances the Alloy Analyzer’s enumeration engine in three ways. First, this project integrates Seabs, an abstract functions-based enumeration strategy, into the Alloy Analyzer and helps ease the adoption of Seabs by developing meta-templates for common types of abstract functions. Second, this project develops a novel enumeration strategy that allows the user to provide interactive guidance. Lastly, this project integrates several open-source enumeration strategies into the Analyzer, giving the user one consolidated toolset to fine-tune enumeration and target relevant scenarios. Moreover, this project improves the visualization of Alloy’s scenarios by generating views that declutter scenarios that span multiple system states and adding an annotated abstract syntax tree to visualize how logical constraints resolve to concrete values over the current scenario.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: FMitF: Formal Methods in the F

por.por_cntn:
Several techniques for enhancing enumeration and visualization of Alloy scenarios were produced by this project. 

Hawkeye: User-Directed Enumeration. Hawkeye allows users to influence the enumeration as it happens [ISSRE 2021]. When a scenario is displayed, Hawkeye lets users select portions of the scenario they wish to keep the same or portions of the scenario they wish to change. Case studies highlight how these features can help detect faults faster. Available at: https://github.com/alloy-extensions/Hawkeye

Reach: Enumerating by Size. A common practice to users is to start with enumerating smaller scenarios and them enumeration larger and larger ones [ISSRE 2022]. Before Reach, this process was done in an ad-hoc, manual way. With Reach, we automate this process. In addition, Reach places a partial order on scenarios of the same size, giving the user an expected order of enumeration. Available at: https://reachextension.github.io/

Abstract Alloy Instances. Abstract instances separate out the portion of the instance generated for the global formulas versus the locally executed formulas. This allows uses to triage faulty scenarios more easily, as they can tell which formulas contribute to the faulty portions of the instance. Available at: https://github.com/jringert/alloy-absinst

Blackbox Evaluator. Alloy instances can be explored using the Evaluator, which returns what expressions or formulas evaluate to for a specific scenario. However, the user gets no insight into why these expressions or formulas produce the values that they do. The blackbox evaluator presents the intermediate evaluations that occur, which effectively provides a trace of the evaluation for the user. Available at: https://github.com/Allisonius/Blackbox_Evaluator

Open source and Education. These tools are all publicly available and are encouraged for use by the formal methods education community. Hawkeye and Reach are good resources to reach formal methods. The blackbox evaluator is a good resource to teach the mathematical logic that underpins modeling languages.

 

 


Last Modified: 05/05/2023
Modified by: Allison Sullivan
